chapter.title: Managing a Virtualization Environment
chapter.para: Apart from using the recommended &libvirt; library (), you can manage &xen; guest domains with the xl tool from the command line.

sect1.title: XL—&xen; Management Tool
sect1.para: The xl program is a tool for managing &xen; guest domains. It is part of the xen-tools package. xl is based on the LibXenlight library, and can be used for general domain management, such as domain creation, listing, pausing, or shutting down. Usually you need to be &rootuser; to execute xl commands.

note.para: xl can only manage running guest domains specified by their configuration file. If a guest domain is not running, you cannot manage it with xl.

tip.para: To allow users to continue to have managed guest domains in the way the obsolete xm command allowed, we now recommend using &libvirt;'s virsh and virt-manager tools. For more information, see .

sect1.para: xl operations rely upon xenstored and xenconsoled services. Make sure you start
at boot time to initialize all the daemons required by xl.

tip.title: Set up a xenbr0 Network Bridge in the Host Domain
tip.para: In the most common network configuration, you need to set up a bridge in the host domain named xenbr0 to have a working network for the guest domains.

listitem.para: xl create creates a virtual machine from a given configuration file.

xl destroy immediately terminates a virtual machine.
xl block-list displays all virtual block devices attached to a virtual machine.

sect2.title: Guest Domain Configuration File
sect2.para: When operating domains, xl requires a domain configuration file for each domain. The default directory to store such configuration files is /etc/xen/.

A domain configuration file is a plain text file. It consists of several KEY=VALUE pairs. Some keys are mandatory, some are general and apply to any guest, and some apply only to a specific guest type (para or fully virtualized). A value can either be a "string" surrounded by single or double quotes, a number, a boolean value, or a list of several values enclosed in brackets [ value1, value2, ... ].

example.title: Guest Domain Configuration File for &sleda; 12: /etc/xen/sled12.cfg
example.screen: name= "sled12" builder = "hvm" vncviewer = 1 memory = 512 disk = [ '/var/lib/xen/images/sled12.raw,,hda', '/dev/cdrom,,hdc,cdrom' ] vif = [ 'mac=00:16:3e:5f:48:e4,model=rtl8139,bridge=br0' ] boot = "n"

sect2.para: To start such domain, run xl create /etc/xen/sled12.cfg.

sect1.title: Automatic Start of Guest Domains
sect1.para: To make a guest domain start automatically after the host system boots, follow these steps:

step.para: Create the domain configuration file if it does not exist, and save it in the /etc/xen/ directory, for example /etc/xen/domain_name.cfg.
Make a symbolic link of the guest domain configuration file in the auto/ subdirectory.
On the next system boot, the guest domain defined in domain_name.cfg will be started.

sect1.title: Time Stamp Counter
sect1.para: The Time Stamp Counter (TSC) may be specified for each domain in the guest domain configuration file (for more information, see ).

With the tsc_mode setting, you specify whether rdtsc instructions are executed natively (fast, but TSC-sensitive applications may sometimes run incorrectly) or emulated (always run correctly, but performance may suffer).

listitem.para: Use this to ensure correctness while providing the best performance possible—for more information, see .
Use this when TSC-sensitive apps are running and worst-case performance degradation is known and acceptable.
Use this when all applications running in this VM are TSC-resilient and highest performance is required.
High-TSC-frequency applications may be paravirtualized (modified) to obtain both correctness and highest performance—any unmodified applications must be TSC-resilient.

sect1.title: Virtual Machine States
sect1.para: A virtual machine’s state can be displayed by viewing the results of the xl list command, which abbreviates the state using a single character.

listitem.para: r - running - The virtual machine is currently running and consuming allocated resources.
b - blocked - The virtual machine’s processor is not running and not able to run. It is either waiting for I/O or has stopped working.
p - paused - The virtual machine is paused. It does not interact with the hypervisor but still maintains its allocated resources, such as memory.
s - shutdown - The guest operating system is in the process of being shut down, rebooted, or suspended, and the virtual machine is being stopped.
c - crashed - The virtual machine has crashed and is not running.
d - dying - The virtual machine is in the process of shutting down or crashing.
